bibl.title: Military Orders for the Cuban People, July 9, 1901

div1.p: Circular #2, written in both English and Spanish, shows that the mosquito is responsible for the spread of disease, in particular yellow fever. The author outlines the necessary precautions that must be taken to prevent the spread of diseases by the mosquito. A summary of other Circulars regarding the spread of diseases is also included. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

CIRCULAR No. 2.

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, July 9, 1901.

By direction of the Military Governor, the follow-
ing circular is published for the information and guid-
ance of all concerned:

The recent medical discoveries concerning, the
part played by mosquitoes in the propagation of cer-
tain diseases are of such vital importance to the com-
fort, health and prosperity of the people of Cuba that
the Military Governor deems it proper to call the
earnest attention not only of every one in authority
but of every patriotic citizen to this subject.

It has been scientifically demonstrated that mala-
rial fever, yellow fever, filariasis and elephantiasis are
transmitted chiefly, if not exclusively, by mosquitoes.
The first two of these diseases, as is well known, are
but too prevalent in Cuba, the cause of many deaths;
thus the mortality from malarial fevers alone was
8220 in the city of Havana during the ten years from
1890 to 1899. Of yellow fever, the scourge which has
made Havana a byword of reproach in the civilized
world, of the thousands of lives for which it is respon-
sible, and the millions of dollars lost to Cuban com-
merce on account of it, nothing more need be said.
Filariasis and elephantiasis are not, fortunately, very
common in Cuba, but enough cases exist in all parts
of the island to make it possible and probable that if
precautions are neglected, infected foci will increase
in number and area.

The above diseases, as already stated, are positive-
ly known to be communicated by mosquitoes which
act as intermediate agents, carrying the infection from
patients to healthy persons. That there are other
diseases thus communicated in tropical countries has
not been proven but is quite probable. It follows then
that the mosquito is one of the most dangerous enemies
we have to contend with and that intelligent self-pre-
servation requires that a relentless war should be wag-
ed against it by all means in our power. The sanitary
-- 2 --
authorities in the island, but especially in Havana,
have already taken energetic measures for the destruc-
tion of mosquitoes and with striking results, results
which amply justify not only the continuation but
extension of these measures. Thus, the yearly mor-
tality from malarial fevers which, as seen above, was
8220 during the decade ending with the year 1899, fell
to 344 in the year 1900, and has only been 75 during the
first six months of this year. The ratio of deaths from
yellow fever to the total non-immune population was
very much less in 1900 than ever before in the history
of Cuba, and during the first six months of this year,
only 17 deaths from that disease have occurred, all in
the months of January, February and March; none in
April, May and June. But the best efforts of the sa-
nitary authorities will only be partially successful and
cannot produce entirely satisfactory results without
the help and cordial cooperation of all persons interest-
ed in the well-being, prosperity and happiness of the
island.

The means employed to prevent infection from
mosquitioes are naturally of two kinds: those aiming
at the destruction of these insects, and those having
for their object the protection of houses and inmates
against their bites by the use of wire screens and bars.
Mosquitoes do not travel far; they generally breed on
the premises which they infect and only fly to the im-
mediately surrounding houses. They lay their eggs in
pools, tanks, tubs, water-barrels, cesspols and sewers,
and within one to three days these eggs hatch into
larvae or wigglers which, within one to two weeks,
become full fledged mosquitoes; hence the necessity of
emptying and removing all useless receptacles in which
water may collect, to fill up holes and ditches and
to cover with board or wire-screen all needful tanks
and water-barrels. A thin film of petroleum poured
on the surface of the water will also prevent mosqui-
toes from laying eggs and destroy all larvae already
hatched. In this work, the Sanitary Department, if
called upon, will afford all necessary and reasonable
assistance.

The use of wire screens on doors and windows
and of bars over beds, is particularly advised, espe-
cially in all public establishments such as hotels,
boarding-houses and other places where non-inmunes
-- 3 --
lodge. The public is becoming educated to the mos-
quito doctrine of the propagation of disease, and
travellers will naturally seek, and be advised to seek,
those hotels and boarding-houses which afford them
the best security against the danger of infection by
mosquitoes. It is therefore of the greatest importance
to all owners and managers of such public establish-
ments that they take all the measures recommended by
the Sanitary Department, not only for the public good
but in their own pecuniary interest. Any establish-
ment which, upon inspection, is found to have adopt-
ed these measures in a satisfactory manner, shall be
given a certificate by the Sanitary Department, stating
the fact and recommending it to all strangers and
non-acclimatized persons.

It is confidently hoped that if the people, especial-
ly those citizens more immediately concerned, will
cöoperate with the authorities, all infected mosquitoes
will be speedily destroyed, yellow fever stamped out
and the other diseases propagated by those insects
reduced to a harmless minimum if not completely
eliminated. This successful warfare against mos-
quitoes, together with the construction of a modern
sewerage system, are the two chief means whereby,
under a good government, thousands of lives are to be
saved, the race physically strengthened, and Havana
made the healthiest and most prosperous of all cities
within the tropics.

EDWARD CARPENTER,
1st. Lieut. Artillery Corps.
Acting Aide-de-Camp.
(Traduccion)
CIRCULAR No. 2.

CUARTEL GENERAL, DEPARTAMENTO DE CUBA,
Habana, 9 de Julio de 1901.

Por disposición del Gobernador Militar, se publi-
ca la siguiente circular para general conocimiento:

De tal importancia son al bienestar, salud y pros-
peridad del pueblo de Cuba las últimas conquistas de
la ciencia médica, relativas al papel que el mosquito
desempeña en la propagación de ciertas enfermedades,
que el Gobernador Militar de Cuba ha considerado de
gran oportunidad el recomendar la más celosa atención
sobre este asunto, no sólo á las autoridades sino que
también á todo ciudadano de civismo.

La ciencia ha demostrado que las fiebres malaria
y amarilla, la filariasis y elefantiasis, si no exclusiva-
mente, son en gran parte trasmitidas por el mosquito.
Ya son casi endémicos en Cuba los dos primeros de
estos males, y, bien se sabe, causa de muchas muertes:
así vemos que durante los diez años transcurridos del
1890 al 99, la mortalidad, á causa de la malaria sola-
mente, fué de 8220 en la ciudad de la Habana. Y
nada habremos de decir de la fiebre amarilla: azote
que hizo de la Habana el mote de reproche del mundo
civilizado, por los miles de víctimas que ha hecho y
por la pérdida de millones de pesos que causó al co-
mercio cubano. Afortunadamente la filariasis y
elefantiasis no son muy frecuentes en Cuba; aunque
existen bastantes casos en algunos puntos de la Isla,
que hacen posible y hasta probable que los focos in-
fecciosos aumenten en número y se extiendan si des-
cuidamos las precauciones necesarias.

Como ya hemos dicho, se sabe positivamente que
todas estas enfermedades se comunican por los mos-
quitos, que actúan de agentes intermediarios llevando
la infección de indivíduos enfermos á los sanos. Que
existen otras enfermedades tropicales que se trasmi-
ten de igual modo, no ha sido aún demostrado; pero
es más que probable. Ahora bien, tenemos que el
-- 6 --
mosquito es uno de los más dañinos enemigos que te-
nemos que combatir, y un buen sentido de propia con-
servación nos exije hacerle guerra sin cuartel por to-
dos los medios á nuestro alcance. Las autoridades
sanitarias de la Isla, y de la Habana especialmente,
ya han venido tomando enérgicas medidas para exter-
minar los mosquitos, y con brillantes resultados; re-
sultados que bien justifican no ya sólo la continuación
sino tambien la ampliación de dichas medidas. Y ve-
mos pues que la mortalidad anual por fiebres malarias
que, como ya dijimos, fué de 8220 en la década que
expira en 1899, desciende á 344 en el año de 1900, y
sólo ha sido de 75 en el primer semestre del año co-
rriente. Ya en 1900 la proporción entre fallecidos
de fiebre amarilla y el total de población no inmune
había sido muchísimo menor de lo que jamás hubiese
sido en Cuba; y en los primeros seis meses del corrien-
te año solo 17 víctimas ha hecho esa enfermedad: to-
das durante los meses de Enero, Febrero y Marzo;
ninguna en Abril, ni en Mayo, ni en Junio. Mas los
mayores esfuerzos de las autoridades sanitarias sólo
parcialmente lograrán su objeto y jamás alcanzarán
satisfactorios resultados, sin el auxilio y cordial coo-
peración de cuantos se interesen por el bienestar,
prosperidad y dicha de esta tierra.

Son, pues, de dos clases los medios empleados
para evitar la infección por el mosquito: Los que
tienden directamente á la destrucción del insecto; y
aquellos cuyo objeto es sólo proteger las viviendas y
sus residentes por medio de la tela metálica y el mos-
quitero. El mosquito no vuela á grandes distancias;
generalmente se procrea en los mismos lugares que
infecta y sólo vuela á las casas inmediatas. Pone sus
huevos en charcas, tanques, tinas, cisternas, letrinas y
cloacas; de entre uno á tres días estos huevos se con-
vierten en larvas ó gusarapos que, transcurridas una ó
dos semanas, se convierten en mosquitos completa-
mente alados. De aquí la necesidad de vaciar todas
las vasijas en que se deposite agua; de llenar todo
hoyo ó agujero y cubrir con tapa ó tela metálica todos
los tanques y depósitos de agua aprovechable. Asi-
mismo vertiendo petróleo líquido de modo que una li-
gera capa cubra la superficie del agua se evitará que
los mosquitos depositen sus huevos y se destruirán
todas las larvas que se hayan desarrollado. En este
-- 7 --
trabajo el Departamento de Sanidad prestará todo auxi-
lio que sea justo y necesario, siempre que se solicite.

Especialmente se recomienda en uso de telas me-
tálicas en puertas y ventanas y el de mosquiteros en
las camas; sobre todo á los establecimientos públicos,
como hoteles, casas de vecindad y demás lugares don-
de se hospeden no inmunes. El público ha venido
comprendiendo fácilmente la teoría de la propagación
de enfermedades por medio del mosquito, y natural-
mente los viajeros buscarán, y se les recomienda,
aquellos hoteles y casas que mejor los aseguren contra
el peligro de infección por el mosquito. Por tanto, de
gran utilidad será á los dueños y administradores de
dichos establecimientos públicos el observar todas las
medidas que el Departamento de Sanidad recomienda,
no sólo en bien público, sino que también en interés
de su propio peculio. Y el Departamento de Sanidad
expedirá un certificado á cualquier establecimiento
que, previa inspección, haya observado estas medidas
de modo satisfactorio; certificado que declarará ese
hecho y recomendará el establecimiento á los extran-
jeros y demás personas no aclimatadas.

Y con gran confianza esperamos que si el pueblo,
y especialmente aquellos individuos á quienes más di-
rectamente concierne, cooperan con las autoridades,
fácilmente lograremos exterminar los mosquitos infec-
ciosos, extirparemos la fiebre amarilla, y, si no ilimina-
mos, al menos reduciremos á grado insignificante las
demás enfermedades que se propagan por medio de
dichos insectos. Esta feliz campaña contra el mosquito
secundada por la construcción de un moderno sistema
de alcantarillas, será el más poderoso medio de que
habremos de valernos para, bajo una buena adminis-
tración, salvar miles de vidas, robustecer físicamente
la raza y convertir la Habana en el más saludable y
próspero de los pueblos tropicales.

EDWARD CARPENTER,
1er. Tte. del Cuerpo de Artillería,
Ayudante de Campo Interino.

Circular No. 22, Department of Santiago & Puerto
Principe, Dec. 21, 1899, publishes general rules for the man-
agement of yellow fever, providing that saloons, hotels, and
other public places shall be frequently inspected; that
non-immunes shall not enter towns infected without special
authority; that physicians and keepers of public places
shall promptly report suspicious cases; that patients shall
be removed to isolation hospitals, when practicable, and
other inmates of the infected house to undergo disinfec-
tion by taking sublimate bath, their clothing, etc., and the
house to be thoroughly disinfected; the latter to remain
vacant at least seven days after disinfection, etc., etc.

Circular No. 2, same department, March 5, 1900, dir-
ects medical officers to seek the cooperation of the Marine
Hospital Service, and in garrison towns and seaports, to
take a census of non-immunes, removing the destitute to the
country, or isolating them; also provides for the establish-
ment of isolation hospitals; that buildings known to have
been infected in previous years shall be inspected, and if
necessary, disinfected; that persons coming from infected
localities shall be isolated for five days and then disin-
fected; and shows how the disease may be diagnosed, etc.

Circular No. 2, Headquarters Department of Cuba,
dated April 27, 1901, after the discovery that yellow fever
is transmitted solely by the bite of infected mosquitos,
provides regulations for preventing the breeding of mosqui-
tos, and limits disinfection of rooms to fumigation for the
purpose of killing mosquitos; provides that suspect cases
and persons coming from infected localities shall be prompt-
ly isolated and protected from mosquitos, &c.

Circular No. 2, Department of Cuba, July 9, 1901,
calls attention of the public generally to above discovery,
and gives instructions for destroying mosquitos and for
protection against their bites, etc.

Also Order No. 65, Department of Cuba, March 7, 1902,
shows that all persons coming from infected places are re-
quired to report to the Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana.
Copies of all of above orders herewith. (next 22)

In this connection see also Part 2, Report of War
Department for 1900, being report of Military Governor of
Cuba, containing article by Maj. V. Harvard, Feb. 9, 1901, entitled
“Sanitation and Yellow Fever in Havana”, and report of Chief Sanitary
Officer of Havana, p. 227, and Vol. 1, Part 3,
Civil Report of Gen. Wood, Jan. 1st to May 20th, 1902, for report
of Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana, giving resume of sani-
tary work, etc., by his department since American occupation,
with particular reference to fighting yellow fever.
